reviewText: I bought this DVD solely for HONDO AND THE APACHES. I was a fan of the series around 1994 when TNT was airing it regularly. When they pulled it I missed it until this DVD came out. Boy was I sorry I bought it.The DVD looks like it was mastered from an old film print, maybe even an old VHS tape due to some of the print damage that looks like video-tape "snow" rather than damage to an old film print. On top of that, it should be 85 minutes long, and is only a mere 72 minutes. The quality of the other film, THE MAN CALLED NOON, is no better. I'm used to cheap budget DVDs, but when parts of the movie are missing, I have to complain.
summary: Love the movie, but hated the DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: I completely agree with the previous writers that both of these movies are bad copies of a not so good VHS copy.  Not only is the picture quality atrocious, in general, the sound is badly muffled in places on "A Man Called Noon" and the colour is all washed out in "Hondo".  Both are shown full screen.  And as one reviewer said, halfway through Noon, the DVD quits.  in Hondo, another viewer tells us 13 min. of film are missing.  No wonder there appears to be Grand Canyon gaps in the story, especially between Robert Taylor's character and his new found son.  I have a VHS copy of Noon and I think it is actually cleaner with better sound."A Man Called Noon" is one of Louis l'Amour's finer novels and the movie benefits from Richard Crenna as Noon, but even more from Stephen Boyd's (Massala in Ben Hur) character JP Rimes.  This movie was shot in either Spain, Mexico, or Italy and has a typical spaghetti western flavour....windy vistas, creaky ghost towns, Serge Leone close-ups and the dead give-away Spanish steam engine made to look like an American engine pulling a Spanish train made to look American.  Stephen Boyd, I think, has always been an under-rated actor and it is so obvious in Ben-Hur after Massala dies, Heston has a hard time carrying the last third of the picture.  Same here.  Although Crenna does well, it is the scenes with Boyd that steal the show.  Overall I would rate it 3.5 stars, mainly because of the crummy DVD presentation ruins a respectable production.Hondo and the Apaches is an MGM production filmed in the US and although a lot of fun to watch, suffers from a lousy DVD presentation, 13 minutes of film missing, and most seriously from none of the Apaches being Apaches.  Veteran Italian actors stand in for tough, hard nosed Apache chiefs.  In fact, Hondo looks more Apache than all of them.  While not even close to John Wayne's portrayal, this one does have its merits...Noah Beery Jr.and Ralph Taegar both give admirable performances as does Kathy Browne, despite the 60s hairstyle....and Robert Taylor's character Gallagher is solid. I give this one 3 stars.  Both of these old oaters deserve a good presentation in original widescreen formats with all the film included.
summary: Poor DVD quality ruins 2 good ole' Oaters!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: One of my favorite Louis L'Amour stories was "The Man Called Noon". Needless to say, the DVD did not do it justice. The quality of "The Sacketts" production was not there. The story was just fair. I was, to be blunt, disappointed. It made a fair gift to a man who loved Westerns.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The reviews and the helpful votes are all over the place for this DVD.There are two things to consider if you are thinking about getting this DVD.First ,the movies themselves, which get good reviews and second, the quality of the DVD itself.I had no trouble with "Hondo And The Apaches" at all.In fact, it is excellent,with a great storyline,lots of Indian involvement,lots of action,and well acted.However;as to "The Man Called Moon",it seems it is also a very good movie ,but there is something wrong with the DVD itself.In fact mine wouldn't play at all.So,what you get here is  a "Buyer Beware"
summary: "What do you plan on doing? Find the pieces  ,try to fit them back together.".
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Jim Phillips "Experience is what you get when...
reviewText: This was written by Louis L'Amour, that adds an authenticity to this that any western fan can appreciate.  When I first saw the title I thought it was a different version of the John Wayne movie 'Hondo' its not.  Although the character bears the same name this is an excellent story in its own right.  I've never seen Ralph Taeger act before but he was very enjoyable.The man called Noon was a good movie in and of itself.  Liked the book more, but isn't that always the case.The DVD itself was about what I expected.  Its not digitally re-mastered and the sound quality sucks but I didn't buy it because I was looking for a technical Masterpiece, I bought it because Louis L'Amour wrote it.  And as far as I am concerned I MORE than got my moneys worth.

reviewText: the hondo movie is two shows from the hondo t.v. series,and i had never heard of the other. i did like both but the disc is so bad(washed out color,sound drops,and the look of a transfer from a video camera and t.v. screen)!!! if you want these look for better copies out there!!!!!

Title: N/A

reviewerName: Rev. Richard Smith D. D "Rev. Smith"
reviewText: Where to begin... I had a VHS copy of this a long time ago, it was lousy, but I thought it was just "the nature of the beast", so to speak. I was hoping that because this was advertised as being remastered, it would be nearly pristine. Guess what? Just as lousy a print as the VHS was. I don't blame either AMAZON or the company that I purchased it through. I received it in good time and the packaging was quite good. It was the print itself that was worse than anyone could expect for a DVD. I returned it for a refund and received the refund in rapid "turn around" time. All in all I would recommend both AMAZON and the company that I purchased it from , HIGHLY. Can't expect any better service than what they provided. Certainly they had no way of knowing that the print of the movie was of very very low quality. I'm truly disappointed that some companies are purveyers of such junk. I wish I could remember the name of THAT company so I could warn you about them. I hope this review helped you.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are a Louis L'Amour fan these are a treat: to see Hondo come alivewas nice. The acting was actually better in the one "A Man called Noon"with Richard Crenna in a early role. The Apaches in the second movie are a little more believable than in most movies about them. Anyone who likes historical westerns will enjoy both of these.
